entry.title: Philosophy or just common sense ?
entry.summary:
Workspace Reading some Paul Graham notes, I found an interesting comment regarding workspace : An office environment is supposed to be something that helps you work, not something you work despite. He is right but how many companies ? organization got the same problem ? have such kind of office environment where it's impossible to work or very difficult to work. My home workspace is, at the moment, very messy due to a large workload and various non-related activities. I'm pretty sure (at least for me) that the very near objects (less than 1 meter) on a desk are affecting the work done or your general ability to focus on a specific work (especially programming). I really don't know why, you know we are a such complex piece of software... we are not all equal in the ability to concentrate. It's time to clean up my desk and better follow the result of the Joel Test... UNIX philosophy and RSS I just tested Plagger a Perl module working as Pluggable RSS/Atom Aggregator with a bunch of extensions/modules. You have a bunch of filters, ways to get feeds and transform/redistribute them in various ways. The modules depend on a bunch of other Perl modules (too much?) but everything else is very good and useable. If you need a way to gather, consolidate RSS/Atoms feeds, Plagger is very nice. Conference business A very good blog entry about conference business, very informative and the comments are quite good. The conference business world has to change its habits of the over-priced conference, non-interactive session and commercial only events. This is really true for a large number of computer-related conferences. Current Reading
The Art of Computer Programming, volume 4, Fascicle 4. Very dense (as usual for Donald Knuth) and more used as reference document for trees (the data structure) and generating all the combination. Apoidea: A Decentralized Peer-to-Peer Architecture for Crawling the World Wide Web. A nice paper and clever use of the Bloom filters.

div.p: Reading some Paul Graham notes, I found an interesting comment regarding workspace : An office environment is supposed to be something that helps you work, not something you work despite. He is right but how many companies ? organization got the same problem ? have such kind of office environment where it's impossible to work or very difficult to work. My home workspace is, at the moment, very messy due to a large workload and various non-related activities. I'm pretty sure (at least for me) that the very near objects (less than 1 meter) on a desk are affecting the work done or your general ability to focus on a specific work (especially programming). I really don't know why, you know we are a such complex piece of software... we are not all equal in the ability to concentrate. It's time to clean up my desk and better follow the result of the Joel Test...

I just tested Plagger a Perl module working as Pluggable RSS/Atom Aggregator with a bunch of extensions/modules. You have a bunch of filters, ways to get feeds and transform/redistribute them in various ways. The modules depend on a bunch of other Perl modules (too much?) but everything else is very good and useable. If you need a way to gather, consolidate RSS/Atoms feeds, Plagger is very nice.

A very good blog entry about conference business, very informative and the comments are quite good. The conference business world has to change its habits of the over-priced conference, non-interactive session and commercial only events. This is really true for a large number of computer-related conferences.

ul.li: The Art of Computer Programming, volume 4, Fascicle 4. Very dense (as usual for Donald Knuth) and more used as reference document for trees (the data structure) and generating all the combination.
Apoidea: A Decentralized Peer-to-Peer Architecture for Crawling the World Wide Web. A nice paper and clever use of the Bloom filters.

entry.title: The "Perl" Conference
entry.summary: So I am looking at the Perl track for OSCON, and I am wondering where the technical sessions are.No offense to any of the speakers or topics, because I am only speaking personally, but I don't really care about most of the non-meaty topics, like Perl Bliss and so on. And I don't care about Perl 6. Feed Aggregation is so 5 years ago. I never pay extra for the tutorials.Setting aside the standards -- Lightning Talks and The Conway Channel -- that leaves me with What's New in Perl DBI, Devel::Cover, Plagger: Pluggable RSS/Atom Aggregation, Mason Components for Ajax, A Relational Object Driver That Doesn't Suck, and Perl Hacks You Never Knew Existed.I don't care about feed aggregation (well, I do, but not in any new tools to deal with it), I don't use Mason (although maybe I could learn something more about how to deal with Ajax), and I sure as hell don't need another DB abstraction layer (although it might be an interesting talk anyway, at least get me thinking about issues with our own custom layer?).So being very generous with my interest, I could go to all the above sessions, which means four sessions Wednesday, three Thursday, and one Friday.And that's with no options for other possibilities. So if one was a dud or I decided I really didn't care about a new syndication aggregation toolkit, I'd have nothing to go to.Of course, I might very well find sessions in the Apache and MySQL tracks. And I will likely go to OSCON and do just that, and not feel like I've wasted my time or money.But I want to go to a Perl conference, and frankly, I don't think OSCON qualifies. Now Playing: John Debney - It Is Done
entry.content:
So I am looking at the Perl track for OSCON, and I am wondering where the technical sessions are.

No offense to any of the speakers or topics, because I am only speaking personally, but I don't really care about most of the non-meaty topics, like Perl Bliss and so on. And I don't care about Perl 6. Feed Aggregation is so 5 years ago. I never pay extra for the tutorials.

Setting aside the standards -- Lightning Talks and The Conway Channel -- that leaves me with What's New in Perl DBI, Devel::Cover, Plagger: Pluggable RSS/Atom Aggregation, Mason Components for Ajax, A Relational Object Driver That Doesn't Suck, and Perl Hacks You Never Knew Existed.

I don't care about feed aggregation (well, I do, but not in any new tools to deal with it), I don't use Mason (although maybe I could learn something more about how to deal with Ajax), and I sure as hell don't need another DB abstraction layer (although it might be an interesting talk anyway, at least get me thinking about issues with our own custom layer?).

So being very generous with my interest, I could go to all the above sessions, which means four sessions Wednesday, three Thursday, and one Friday.

And that's with no options for other possibilities. So if one was a dud or I decided I really didn't care about a new syndication aggregation toolkit, I'd have nothing to go to.

Of course, I might very well find sessions in the Apache and MySQL tracks. And I will likely go to OSCON and do just that, and not feel like I've wasted my time or money.

But I want to go to a Perl conference, and frankly, I don't think OSCON qualifies.

Now Playing: John Debney - It Is Done

entry.title: Some interesting Plagger thingies.
entry.summary: Looks like there will be a Plagger Talk at Oscon this year. Wish I could be there. Plagger seems to be very shiny, I've been playing a little with it lately. It's also going to get RSS Event support, which will be very interesting with the advent of GCal.

content.div: Looks like there will be a Plagger Talk at Oscon this year. Wish I could be there. Plagger seems to be very shiny, I've been playing a little with it lately. It's also going to get RSS Event support, which will be very interesting with the advent of GCal.

entry.title: O'Reilly Open Source Convention - July, 24-28, 2006 - Portland, OR
entry.summary: Plagger (http://plagger.org/) is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation and syndication tool written in Perl. Plagger comes with various API hooks that external plugins can extend: Subscription, Aggregator, Custom Feed, Filter/Tag Content, Content Widget & Publish. With these plugin hooks, you can do pretty neat stuff like "Get the updates from Bloglines, create rich-text email and forward them all to my Gmail inbox. But if the entry title contains 'OSCON' and is bookmarked by more than 10 users on del.icio.us, ...
entry.content: Plagger (http://plagger.org/) is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation and syndication tool written in Perl. Plagger comes with various API hooks that external plugins can extend: Subscription, Aggregator, Custom Feed, Filter/Tag Content, Content Widget & Publish. With these plugin hooks, you can do pretty neat stuff like "Get the updates from Bloglines, create rich-text email and forward them all to my Gmail inbox. But if the entry title contains 'OSCON' and is bookmarked by more than 10 users on del.icio.us, ...

entry.title: Balham Blogs
entry.summary:
Been I while since I did anything really geeky in my spare time so this weekend (whilst watching the UKTV repeats of last year's Doctor Who) I went back to a project that I was thinking about a few months ago.
I've build Balham Blogs. It's a site that aggregates RSS feeds that have some connection with Balham. I was going to use the Planet software, but last week someone mentioned Plagger to me and as it's a Perl toolkit I used that instead.
Plagger is still under heavy development and the documentation leaves a little to be desired. I had to resort to reading code a few times in order to work out what I needed to do. But in the end it only took a few hours to get the site up and running.
If you run a site that produces an RSS (or Atom, I'm not fussy) feed that has somethi ng to do with Balham, then please let me know and I'll be happy to add it.

div.p: Been I while since I did anything really geeky in my spare time so this weekend (whilst watching the UKTV repeats of last year's Doctor Who) I went back to a project that I was thinking about a few months ago.

I've build Balham Blogs. It's a site that aggregates RSS feeds that have some connection with Balham. I was going to use the Planet software, but last week someone mentioned Plagger to me and as it's a Perl toolkit I used that instead.

Plagger is still under heavy development and the documentation leaves a little to be desired. I had to resort to reading code a few times in order to work out what I needed to do. But in the end it only took a few hours to get the site up and running.
If you run a site that produces an RSS (or Atom, I'm not fussy) feed that has somethi ng to do with Balham, then please let me know and I'll be happy to add it.

entry.title: Plagger
entry.summary: Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom feed aggregator written in Perl. Everything is implemented as a small plugin and you can mash them up together using Plagger core API and plugin hooks. You can think of Plagger as a blosxom or qpsmtpd for RSS aggregator.

content.div: Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom feed aggregator written in Perl. Everything is implemented as a small plugin and you can mash them up together using Plagger core API and plugin hooks. You can think of Plagger as a blosxom or qpsmtpd for RSS aggregator.

entry.title: Plagger 0.6.1 (Default branch)
entry.summary: Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation andsyndication software. All the features areimplemented as small plugins.License: Perl LicenseChanges:Adds a new feed upgrade framework called CustomFeed::Simple and Filter::EntryFullText. Improves HTML encoding auto-detection.
entry.content:
Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation andsyndication software. All the features areimplemented as small plugins.License: Perl LicenseChanges:
Adds a new feed upgrade framework called CustomFeed::Simple and Filter::EntryFullText. Improves HTML encoding auto-detection.

entry.title: Plagger 0.6.1 (Default branch)
entry.summary:
Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation and syndication software. All the features are implemented as small plugins.
License: Perl License
Changes: Adds a new feed upgrade framework called CustomFeed::Simple and Filter::EntryFullText. Improves HTML encoding auto-detection.

content.div:
Plagger is a pluggable RSS/Atom aggregation and syndication software. All the features are implemented as small plugins.
License: Perl License
Changes:
Adds a new feed upgrade framework called CustomFeed::Simple and Filter::EntryFullText. Improves HTML encoding auto-detection.
